item.title: Long COVID Breakthrough: Spike Proteins Persist in Brain for Years - SciTechDaily
item.description:
Long COVID Breakthrough: Spike Proteins Persist in Brain for Years

Date: 29 November 2024 | Source: Cell Host & Microbe

Researchers have discovered that the SARS-CoV-2 spike protein persists in the brain and skull bone marrow for years after infection, potentially leading to chronic inflammation and neurodegenerative diseases.

Key Points:

  • The SARS-CoV-2 spike protein can linger in the brain’s protective layers and skull bone marrow for up to four years.
  • The spike protein's presence may lead to chronic inflammation and increased risk of neurodegenerative diseases.
  • mRNA vaccines significantly reduce spike protein levels in the brain.
  • The research employs a novel AI-powered imaging technique to visualize previously undetectable spike protein distributions.
  • Approximately 400 million individuals globally may carry significant amounts of spike protein caused by Long COVID.
“This is not just an individual health issue – it is a societal challenge.” – Prof. Ali Ertürk

The findings open new avenues for diagnosing and treating long-term neurological effects of COVID-19 and suggest a need for further research and therapeutic interventions.

item.title: What US Surgeon General says about drinking and cancer risk - The Indian Express
item.description:
US Surgeon General Warns About Alcohol and Cancer Risks

Publication Date: Last Week
Source: The New York Times

According to a new report by the US Surgeon General, alcohol is the third leading preventable cause of cancer in the United States, prompting a call for warning labels on alcoholic beverages similar to those on cigarettes.

  • Alcohol use is linked to 100,000 cancer cases and 20,000 related deaths annually.
  • The report presents evidence that even moderate drinking can increase cancer risks for breast, mouth, and throat cancers.
  • Four mechanisms by which alcohol leads to cancer include DNA damage, oxidation and inflammation, increased carcinogen absorption from tobacco, and hormone production.
  • Types of cancers associated with alcohol use include breast, colon, esophagus, liver, mouth, throat, and larynx cancers.
“The risk for cancers of the breast, the mouth and the throat may rise with consumption of as little as one drink a day.” - Dr. Vivek Murthy

The report details that the likelihood of developing an alcohol-related cancer increases with the amount consumed, emphasizing the importance of public awareness regarding alcohol and cancer risks.

item.title: Scientists Discover Common Virus Could Be Causing a Type of Alzheimer's - ScienceAlert
item.description:
Scientists Discover Common Virus Could Be Causing a Type of Alzheimer's

Publication Date: 2024-12-19 Source: Science Alert

Researchers have discovered a link between a chronic gut infection caused by a common virus and the development of Alzheimer's disease in some individuals.

  • The study identifies cytomegalovirus (CMV) as a potential causal factor in Alzheimer’s disease, particularly in a specific subset of individuals.
  • By age 80, 90% of people will have antibodies for CMV, but only a small subset experiences chronic intestinal infection.
  • The active virus may travel up the gut-brain axis, aggravating the immune system and potentially leading to Alzheimer’s.
  • Researchers are exploring antiviral treatments to potentially prevent this subtype of Alzheimer’s.
"We think we found a biologically unique subtype of Alzheimer's that may affect 25 percent to 45 percent of people with this disease," said Ben Readhead, lead author from Arizona State University.

This research highlights the need for further investigation into the relationship between chronic infections and neurodegenerative diseases.

item.title: Pupil Dynamics During Sleep Reveal Brain’s Memory-Saving Secrets - Neuroscience News
item.description:
Pupil Dynamics During Sleep Reveal Brain’s Memory-Saving Secrets

Date: January 1, 2023
Source: Cornell University

Researchers at Cornell University have found that pupil size during non-REM sleep plays a crucial role in memory consolidation. This study demonstrates that contracted pupils correlate with the consolidation of new memories, while dilated pupils relate to the processing of older memories.

  • Pupil Size and Memory: Contracted pupils correlate with new memory consolidation, while dilated pupils process older memories.
  • Memory Separation: The brain alternates between new and old knowledge during non-REM sleep to prevent interference.
  • AI Applications: Insights into memory processing may help improve efficiency in artificial neural networks.
The eyes may be the window to the soul, but the pupil is key to understanding how, and when, the brain forms strong, long-lasting memories, Cornell researchers have found.

The findings offer potential for developing better memory enhancement techniques and deeper understanding of sleep's role in memory processing.
